text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC has John McCain now fallen too
far behind too late in the presidential
campaign to overtake Barack Obama just
three weeks before Election Day that's
the question facing strategists in both
parties history suggests the answer is
probably but Obama's breakthrough as the
first african-american nominee has
already made history and represents a
wild card that could yield election
returns at odds with poll results
McCain's hopes rest on dominating
last-minute decisions by those still
undecided and shaking loose some voters
now backing his Democratic rival McCain
trails 50% to forty three percent
through sunday in the gallop tracking
poll of registered voters his deficit in
that survey has remained seven
percentage points or more for most of
the last two weeks since gallup began
presidential polling in 1936 only one
candidate has overcome a deficit that
large this late to win the white house
that was ronald reagan who trailed
President Jimmy Carter forty-seven
percent to thirty-nine percent in a
survey completed october twenty six
nineteen eighty the pattern since
polling began is that opinion swings get
smaller as Election Day approaches and
voters have accumulated more information
as American politics have grown more
polarized the opportunity for large
swings has grown smaller still according
to Princeton political scientists Larry
bartels front-running candidates have
typically preserved three-fourths of
their October leads applying statistical
theory to current polls Bartels pegs
Obama's chance of winning the popular
vote at a little over ninety percent he
noted three factors that might skew the
results two of them potential turnout
surge in the tendency of late deciders
to punish the party holding the White
House in economic downturns appear to
favor Obama the third racial resistance
among white voters would favor McCain
the McCain campaign sees little
opportunity for eroding Obama's near
monolithic support from fellow African
Americans and two to one edge among
Hispanics but strategist for the Arizona
senator figure one in five white voters
roughly fifteen percent of the
electorate remain open to persuasion the
campaign says those persuadable voters
tend to be younger single less educated
and female they also include some senior
distressed over sagging investments
they're the targets for recent McCain
attacks on Obama's ties to one time
Weather Underground figure William Ayers
if one third of them shift allegiance
from Obama to McCain they produce a 10
percentage points swing wiping out
Obama's currently Obama strategists
insists voter preferences have hardened
enough to make that difficult and McCain
strategists acknowledge it won't be easy
